artefact.overview: To grow hemp in the UK, you need a licence from the Home Office
artefact.licence_short_description: To grow hemp in the UK, you need a licence from the Home Office
artefact.licence_overview:
To grow hemp in the UK, you need a licence from the [Home Office.](http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/ "Home Office"){:rel="external:}

You must apply using the online application form on the Home Office Drugs Licensing website. You must register with the [Home Office online](http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/drugs/licensing/domestic-licences/companies "Home Office online"){:rel="external") and submit the MD 29 application form electronically.

You must provide your contact details and the other following information:

- field location numbers, names or grid references
- hectarage details
- farm map with a marked growing area
- seed type, THC content and confirmation of whether this is a European Union approved seed

^You must pay the relevant fee with your application. New licences usually cost £580, with licence renewals costing £326.^

To be eligible for a licence you must also undergo an enhanced CRB check.

Your application may be subject to a compliance visit, although this is rare. Generally applications are considered through the 'light touch regime' process which involves assessing your electronic application only.

##Conditions

The Home Office may impose restrictions on where you plant the crop. They may also request that you screen your crop or locate your crop sensitively - eg not in the vicinity of schools or areas of public access.

You must inform the Home Office of any changes to your growing season or planting location. You must send full details of your changes and your application reference or licence number. Your licence will not need to be amended.

You should also information your local police of your growing location.

You must hold the licence before you can begin to grow hemp.

Licences last for a growing season, and you must renew your licence before you can begin to grow for the next season.
